titleStmt.title: Modeling Decision-Making in Schizophrenia: Associations Between Computationally Derived Risk Propensity and Self-Reported Risk Perception

affiliation.orgName: Brain Health Institute *Corresponding Author Emma Herms
Brain Health Institute *Corresponding Author Emma Herms

analytic.title: Modeling Decision-Making in Schizophrenia: Associations Between Computationally Derived Risk Propensity and Self-Reported Risk Perception

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Background and Hypothesis Schizophrenia is associated with decreased pursuit of risky rewards during uncertain-risk decision-making. However, putative mechanisms subserving this disadvantageous risky reward pursuit, such as contributions of cognition and relevant traits, remain poorly understood.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder (henceforth SZ) are chronic conditions characterized by cognitive impairment, atypical beliefs, and decreased reward/goal pursuit, which contribute to ongoing functional impairment. 1 SZ has been associated with poor decisionmaking linked to difficulties learning the probabilities of decision outcomes. It has been theorized that this disadvantageous decision-making is due to an inability to manipulate information, so as to accurately balance potential for rewards relative to risks and accordingly adjust choices. [2][3] This lack of accurate "risk perception" results in those with SZ inadvertently pursuing rewards in some contexts with a higher risk of failure, while not pursuing rewards in other contexts in which it would be more advantageous to do so. 4,71 People with SZ consistently pursue rewards less than comparison participants (henceforth CP) in situations entailing uncertain risk (i.e., likelihoods of aversive outcomes are learned across time via trial-and-error). [4][5][6] This maladaptive unwillingness to tolerate the risk of failure limits opportunities to gain new or additional rewards and resources (e.g., nothing ventured, nothing gained). More broadly, impaired risky, effort-based, and reinforcement decision-making have been associated with lower hedonic tone and cognitive functioning in SZ, [7][8][9][10][11][12] and this altered decision-making is compounded by adjacent processes such as less goal pursuit associated with defeatist beliefs. [13][14] Though some work suggests greater perceived risk of potential neutral and negative events in SZ, 15 it remains unclear how risk specific processes (perceived risk, expected benefits of risk-taking), and non-risk specific traits (defeatist beliefs, hedonic tone) contribute to uncertain-risk decision-making. The current study examines these processes in relation to SZ and aims to inform future interventions by elucidating whether adaptive reward pursuit may be impacted by perception of risk, defeatist beliefs, or hedonic tone.

The Balloon Analogue Risk Task (BART) is a commonly employed task measuring decision-making under uncertain-risk. 16 In the BART, participants choose to inflate a virtual balloon, increasing the amount of monetary reward the balloon is worth while simultaneously increasing the likelihood the balloon explodes. Risk-taking on the BART is typically quantified as adjusted pumps (average inflations on trials with unexploded balloons) and participants with psychosis tend to take less risk in the form of fewer inflations. 5,12,[17][18][19][20] However, the metric of adjusted pumps offers no insight into subprocesses underlying task behavior. In contrast, theoretically informed computational models of the BART parse decision-making into subprocesses, like risk-taking tendencies and learning over trials, to identify what contributes to disadvantageous uncertain-risk reward pursuit in psychosis.

Decision-making under uncertain-risk conditions relies on risk perception, or the process of integrating information to learn and weigh relative outcome probabilities to formulate an accurate understanding of risk situations, which is interrelated with broader cognitive processes. 21 To optimize advantageous risk-taking on the BART, participants must integrate information across trials to discern the probability of potential reward relative to the balloon exploding. Research has suggested that decision-making in psychosis is characterized by an impaired ability to integrate task information to accurately perceive risk and make advantageous decisions. 4,10,17 This proposed risk imperception in psychosis may be partially due to established general cognitive deficits, [22][23][24] as several studies in psychosis have found associations between measures of cognition and risk-taking behavior, 2,12,[25][26][27][28] as well as cognition and reinforcement learning broadly. 29 On the BART specifically, three studies have reported correlations between adjusted pumps and cognitive measures in psychosis. 5,12,30 In contrast, most of the other studies on the topic have not tested or even controlled for this potential confound, despite reporting lower general intelligence (i.e., IQ) in psychosis groups relative to CP. 4 The current study addresses this weakness by matching participants on IQ, and evaluating whether group differences on computational subprocess of uncertain-risk decision-making are associated with IQ.

Further, we utilize self-reported risk-specific processes (i.e., perceived risks/benefits in everyday life scenarios) and non-risk specific traits to specifically characterize computational parameters of risk-taking tendencies. Self-reported risk-specific processes have not been examined in psychosis but may be critical contextualizing factors of uncertain-risk decisionmaking. Utilizing self-report measures of perceived risk, and separately expected benefit of risk, the current study tests whether either of these different processes contribute to differences in risk-taking tendencies on the BART. Non-risk specific traits of a tendency to hold more defeatist beliefs and lower hedonic tone are closely related to common negative symptoms of avolition and anhedonia, respectively. [31][32] These traits are theorized to impact decision-making through decreased motivation to pursue goal-directed behavior and/or decreased sensitivity to reward. 6,28,33 However, there is mixed support for relationships between these constructs and decision-making in schizophrenia. 5,17,[25][26] The current study examines whether defeatist performance beliefs and hedonic tone contribute to differences in risk-taking tendencies on the BART, to preclude the possibility that risk-taking tendencies were better explained by non-risk specific traits.

Taken together, the current study is the first to use computational modeling of the BART to examine subprocesses of uncertain-risk decision-making in SZ. Our first aim was to test between-group differences in subprocess parameters of uncertain-risk decision-making and subsequently examine whether parameters with group differences correlated with cognitive functioning (IQ). We hypothesized group differences in both risk-taking tendencies and learning rate, which would be associated with IQ, given reduced uncertain-risk decision-making and impaired reinforcement learning in psychosis, 5,34 and previous associations between risk-taking, learning on tasks, and cognitive function. 12,35 Our second aim was to test our hypothesis that computationally derived parameters of risk-taking would be predicted by self-reported risk perception and expected benefits of risks in SZ, 4,15 above and beyond IQ, rather than non-risk specific processes of hedonic tone and defeatist beliefs. 7,14 2. Methods

div.head: Participants & Study Design
div.p: A sample of 30 participants with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder (SZ) and 30 age, sex, race, and IQ matched CP with no psychiatric history was utilized. Diagnoses were confirmed via Structured Clinical Interview (SCID-IV; see Table 1). Details regarding eligibility, education, and income are included in Supplementary Section 1.1 and Table S1. Participation lasted 6-8 hours over two laboratory visits. During the first visit, participants completed demographic information and clinical/cognitive assessments. The second visit consisted of BART practice, task-based fMRI, and self-report measures. fMRI findings have been previously published. 30 To characterize the sample, group averages and t-tests are reported in Table 1 for demographic, cognitive assessments, self-reported risk-specific processes, and non-risk specific traits. Full-sample Shapiro-Wilk normality tests were used to assess the normality of all variables. Non-parametric tests were used for defeatist performance beliefs and hedonic tone, as they had non-normal distributions (see Table S3); however, results were consistent when using parametric tests on transformed variables.

div.head: Modified fMRI Balloon Analogue Risk Task
div.p: In this modified BART, each trial began with a balloon worth $0, and each inflation increased the explosion probability and reward magnitude ( Figure S1, Table S2). Thus, risk and reward are highly correlated. The current value of the balloon (e.g., after 4 inflations "Wager: $0.55") and the accumulated earnings across trials (e.g., "Total: $6.75") were continuously displayed. For each inflation, the participant chose to inflate the balloon or cash out. On successful inflation, the balloon expands and the wager increases. If the balloon exploded, it would be followed by "You Lose!". Instead, if the participant chose to cash out, it would be followed by "You Win!", and the total earnings would be updated. Each balloon could be inflated a maximum of 12 times. Behavioral and modified fMRI BART versions have demonstrated moderate to high test-retest reliability in behavior and brain activation. [36][37][38] Participants were read instructions and practiced inflating several balloons (average number of practice trials, SZ: M = 4.58, SD = 0.89; CT: M = 4.48, SD = 1.05; p = 0.79) on a desktop computer. Task practice was briefer than previous fMRI-based studies, 39,40 allowing participants to gain familiarity with task mechanics (e.g., fMRI-imposed delays) without learning the underlying explosion probabilities. If at least 1 practice balloon was not inflated at least 4 times, subjects were given the vague, nonchalant instruction "Go ahead and give this last balloon a few more pumps" on the final practice trial to ensure they were aware the balloon could be inflated at least 4 times. After the conclusion of practice trails participants waited at least 30 minutes before the initiation of actual BART fMRI-based data collection. During this interval, participants completed practice trials for a separate task and other MRI related procedures (e.g.,

ambulating to the imaging suite, safety screening, changing clothes, setup scans). This instruction was never restated after the practice (e.g., prior to actual BART data collection). See Supplementary Section 1.2 for full rationale.

The BART was then completed over three 8-minute blocks during fMRI. Task behavior impacts the number of trials completed, as inflating balloons eight times is more time consuming than inflating balloons twice (average number of trials, SZ: M = 51.80, SD = 7.70; CT:

div.head: Computational Modeling: Models, Implementation, and Comparison
div.p: The reparametrized four-parameter computational model (Par4) 41,42 Figure S2).

div.head: Hypotheses and Statistical Analyses
div.p: After identifying the best fitting computational model (see section 2.3), our first aim tested two hypotheses related to group differences in computational subprocesses of the BART.

We hypothesized (H1) participants with SZ would exhibit lower values for parameters of risktaking tendencies (i.e., γ/ρ) and Learning Rate (i.e., η/ξ) relative to CP, due to previous findings of less risk-taking on the BART and impaired reinforcement learning based decision-making. with risk-taking tendencies and learning rate, aligning with previous correlations between similar metrics and cognition. 5,12,30,35 Full sample correlations were performed, unless within-group correlation coefficients significantly differed between groups, determined via Fisher's Z test.

Additionally, computational parameters with credible differences between groups were assessed for associations with neuroleptic medication, which were standardized to oral chlorpromazine (CPZ) equivalent doses within the SZ group. 58 13 and more specifically implicated in both effort-based and reinforcement learning decision-making. 7,14,59 Thus, we included measures to determine the specificity of decision-making deficits in relation to risk-specific, rather than general, traits in SZ. It was hypothesized (H3) that Perceived Risk and Expected Benefit of financial risk-taking would be negatively and positively associated with risk-taking parameters, respectively. It was also hypothesized (H4) that defeatist beliefs and hedonic tone would not predict risk-taking, based on inconsistent associations with decision-making in schizophrenia. 5,17,[25][26] Due to likely differential relationships across SZ and CP in these hypothesized main effects, an interaction term between group and the self-reported construct was included in all models. IQ was used as a covariate in all models to determine whether relationships between risk-taking tendencies with group and self-report construct of interest remained when controlling for IQ. Due to the fundamental role of multiple cognitive processes in decision-making, and a potential general deficit across decision-making tasks in psychosis, 60 even after matching groups based on IQ, it is important to ensure we are capturing risk-specific processes rather than cognition. Thus, for models with significant interactions between group and the self-report construct of interest, specificity analyses examined an interaction with IQ (instead of group), to preclude the possibility that variance was better explained by IQ. Assumptions were checked for each linear model (performance package). 61 Nevertheless, the parameter recovery for the Par4 model was still successful in that for every parameter in both groups, the correlation between true and recovered parameters was significant (except for Prior Belief in the CP group), which indicates that the recovered parameters tracked the true underlying signal up to a monotonic transform. Moreover, since the Par4 model showed similar biases in posterior predictive checks and parameter recovery for both groups, the order of the values is expected to be preserved and thus the parameter estimates were compared across groups. To partially address this general bias in estimating the computational parameters, Spearman correlations, which rely on rank rather than precise values, were used instead of Pearson correlations. However, coefficients are similar when using Spearman and

div.head: Computational Model Comparison
div.p: Pearson correlations, and there is no indication of non-linear relationships. The reliability of the Par4 parameter recovery is further confirmed in that Supplemental Table S5 shows stronger recovered group differences for Risk Propensity and Prior Belief, and less so for learning rate and inverse temperature, which matches the relative effect sizes shown in Figure 1B. Crucially, for the Risk Propensity parameter, which is used in analyses toward our second aim, there was evidence of successful recovery of true signal in the form of significant correlations between true and recovered parameters for both SZ and CP populations, and we consistently recovered the group difference in Risk Propensity during simulations (Supplemental Table S5).

div.head: Group differences in model parameters
div.p: The SZ group exhibited lower Risk Propensity (γ) compared to CP. As displayed in Figure 1B,

div.head: Linear models testing impact of risk-related processes
div.p: Expected Benefit of financial risk did not predict Risk Propensity (β = 0.22, p = 0.23),
nor was there a significant interaction between Expected Benefit and group (β = -0.14, p = 0.55; Table S9).

div.head: Linear models testing impact of non-risk specific traits on Risk Propensity
div.p: Consistent with our hypotheses, defeatist beliefs did not predict Risk Propensity (β = 0.07, p = 0.78), and there was no interaction between defeatist beliefs and group (β = -0.12, p = 0.67). Similarly, hedonic tone did not predict Risk Propensity (β = -0.05, p = 0.78), nor was there a significant interaction between hedonic tone and group (β = 0.26, p = 0.27). See Table S9 for full model information. were positively correlated within the SZ group, but not significantly correlated within the CP group. Before graphing, Risk Propensity (γ) was residualized to remove the variance explained by IQ, which was a covariate in the model. B) Interaction between Perceived Risk and IQ from Model 2. The interaction between Perceived Risk and IQ is across the full sample; to graph the interaction we used a median split of IQ (median = 109.5), which resulted in an equal number of SZ and CP participants above (represented in green) and below (represented in purple) the median. Perceived Risk and Risk Propensity (γ) were positively correlated within the below median IQ group, but not significantly correlated within the above median IQ group Before graphing, Risk Propensity (γ) was residualized to remove the variance explained by group. Spearman rank correlations (rho = R) are reported for each group.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Impaired decision-making in SZ has been attributed to various constructs across behavioral tasks (e.g., reinforcement learning, less effort allocation, jumping to conclusions). 62,63 In uncertain-risk decision-making tasks, including the BART, people with SZ are less willing to pursue risky rewards. This behavior is disadvantageous, as it results in less rewards, and is highly consistent across the psychosis-spectrum. 4 This is the first study to utilize computational modeling of BART behavior in SZ, to examine theoretically driven subprocesses that underlie reward pursuit under conditions of uncertain risk, increasing our understanding of this decisionmaking impairment in SZ.

Utilizing the Par4 model, decision-making was parsed into computationally derived subprocesses. Under our first aim, we identified less Risk Propensity (γ), greater Prior Belief of Success (φ), and intact Learning Rates (η) in SZ relative to CP. Importantly, these findings were consistent in the EWMV model (Supplemental Section 2.4) and findings for Risk Propensity and Learning Rate were replicable in parameter recovery simulations (Supplemental Table S5). Our main finding of decreased Risk Propensity in SZ, and its association with IQ in the full sample, is consistent with previous literature on the BART. Psychosis samples consistently demonstrate decreased uncertain-risk reward pursuit, which is related to, but may not be fully explained by cognition. 5,12,30 Impaired learning has been heavily implicated in reinforcement-based decisionmaking tasks, 57 with some evidence suggesting more indiscriminately exploratory behavior and disruptions in striatum-mediated signals of reward learning. [64][65] Though reward-learning is commonly disrupted across other tasks in SZ, our findings suggest disadvantageous BART behavior is more associated with risk-taking tendencies than differences in learning rates.

Additionally, the groups differed in Prior Belief of Success, such that participants with SZ believed the balloon was less likely to explode. However, the effect size was small showing small to no correlations between self-reported measures of risk-taking and task-based risk-taking. 16,66 In contrast, self-reported Perceived Risk may help contextualize the impaired uncertainrisk decision-making often observed in psychosis. Within our SZ group, those with lower Perceived Financial Risk on the DOSPERT tended to have lower computationally derived Risk Propensity. Since our data is correlational, it does not suggest a homogenous failure across all participants with SZ, but those reporting lower Perceived Financial Risks tended to engage in less advantageous risk-taking. Whereas individuals with SZ reporting higher Perceived Financial Risks pursued more advantageous uncertain-risk rewards, such that their behavior aligned more closely with CP. This relationship is in the opposite direction of our third hypothesis but lends some support to the Risk Imperception hypothesis of psychosis, 4,71 which asserts that poorer decision-making in SZ may not be due to risk-averse attitudes, but rather an inability to accurately perceive situational risk, and discern the appropriateness of when to adaptively pursue uncertain rewards despite risk. Difficulty perceiving the relatively increasing risk levels may result in estimating the probability of explosion on each balloon as closer to chance (e.g., 50/50), rather than the actual, lower explosion probabilities that increase with each subsequent inflation.
This increased noise while gauging risk could contribute to less risky behavior, as potential losses generally loom larger than gains.

The adjacent construct, the expected benefit from risk-taking was hypothesized to be associated with more willingness to embrace risk (regardless of whether risk-level is accurately perceived or not) for anticipated rewards/benefits in the full sample. This may be likened to increased reward sensitivity increasing reward pursuit, rather than decreased perception of risk.

However, our current findings in SZ suggest that decreased risk-taking on the task is associated with perceived risk, rather than the expected benefit of taking risk. Further research directly testing these findings is necessary, as our measure of Perceived Risks reflects how more/less risky an assortment of situations are perceived to be, not necessarily the ability to discriminate between objectively low and high-risk situations.

div.head: It is important to highlight that the above finding between Perceived Financial Risk and
div.p: Risk Propensity is not strictly limited to people with SZ. In support of the role of risk perception for advantageous risk-taking on the BART, we also identified a significant interaction between IQ and Perceived Financial Risk, although the effect size was smaller. This interaction suggests regardless of group (SZ or CP), among individuals with below median IQ, lower Perceived Similarly, defeatist beliefs and hedonic tone were unrelated to Risk Propensity. Together this suggests that group differences in risk-attitude were not better explained by decreased motivation to pursue goal-directed behaviors or decreased sensitivity to reward.

Taken together, the current study triangulated computational modeling of behavior, IQ, and self-report measures of real-world financial situations, to identify disadvantageous BART behavior in SZ is more associated with risk-taking tendencies than learning rates. Furthermore, perception of risk and IQ may be critical to understanding disadvantageous uncertain-risk reward pursuit more generally. While these findings are derived from computer-based laboratory tasks, they expand understanding of reward and goal pursuit in SZ. By better characterizing decisions within this uncertainty/risk-taking framework, our work can inform efforts to identify intervention targets to upregulate strategic reward pursuit (i.e., behavioral activation), despite inherent risk of reward failure, in folks with SZ. Figure 2). Across groups, the Par4 model underestimated observed adjusted pumps when observed adjusted pumps ≥5. However, given the narrow range of observed adjusted pumps in CP, we are unable to compare the model's accuracy across groups at lower observed adjusted pumps (i.e., ≤ 4 observed adjusted pumps).

div.head: Limitations & Other considerations
div.p: Third, the study was powered to detect a medium effect (Supplementary Section 2.7) and may be underpowered to detect small-to-medium effect sizes, particularly among our interaction terms. Given both the poor parameter recovery and small sample size, our linear models require replication. Finally, the Likelihood of Risk-Taking Behavior subscale from the DOSPERT was not administered to reduce experiment burden and because those with the disruptive symptoms of SZ may have less financial access and fewer experiential opportunities to engage in the activities listed (i.e., betting a whole day's income, casino gambling, sports betting, and investment ventures), which may make endorsements on this subscale more speculative, or less comparable to controls. [68][69] Even those with high prevalence of financial risk-taking in SZ report other types of gambling not included on the DOSPERT such as scratch-offs, lottery, and video lottery. 70 Thus, we are not able to determine willingness to engage in risky activity as a function of Perceived Risk.

Future research, ideally in a larger sample, is necessary to replicate current findings. We also encourage future work utilizing self-report measures of risk-specific processes, which are often not included in larger datasets of the BART but may help contextualize computationally derived subprocesses of BART behavior. Task Instructions: "In this part of the session, you will press buttons to complete a task on the computer screen. At the beginning of each block of trials, you may briefly see a "plus" sign in the middle of the screen for a while. Please just look at the plus sign until it disappears.

After that, you will see a small balloon appear in the middle of the screen. Your goal is to inflate the balloon as much as possible without popping it. The more you inflate the balloon, the more money the balloon is worth. When you choose to stop inflating the balloon, you can keep the amount of virtual winnings according to how inflated the balloon is. If instead you inflate the balloon and it pops, then you win nothing for that balloon.

Just below the balloon is a small red or green square. When the square is red, you must wait. When the square turns green, you may press the (LEFT/RIGHT) index finger buttons to keep inflating the balloon or press the (RIGHT/LEFT) index finger button to take your winnings.

Also, after you press either button there will be a little delay. Sometimes there will be no delay and other times it could last a few seconds. Please only hit the button once and wait for the balloon on the screen to respond.

Your ultimate goal is to maximize the number of points you earn. At the end of the session, we will convert a portion of your cumulative winnings on the screen into bonus money and pay you the bonus, in addition to your standard hourly payment. Your running point total will be displayed at the bottom of the screen. Do you have any questions?"

Practice Trials: Participants completed a very small number of practice trials (range 3-7) compared to prior studies (8 mins in Fukunaga et al., 2012; 5 mins in Tikàsz et al., 2019) and the actual 24-minutelong experimental period (range of 36-77 trials). Task practice was completed solely to ensure that subjects understood: 1) the mechanics of the task, including imposed delays necessary in the task, and 2) that the balloon could inflate at least 4 times. The experimenter observed practice and it was discontinued once participants demonstrated understanding of task mechanics. If at least 1 practice balloon was not inflated at least 4 times, subjects were given the vague, nonchalant instruction "Go ahead and give this last balloon a few more pumps," to ensure they were aware the balloon could be inflated at least 4 times. Importantly, the instruction was not given until the end of practice trials on the last balloon. Thus, participants had already made several inflations independently to potentially establish their general task behavior (Schürmann, Frey, & Pleskac, 2019). This instruction may actually limit the impact of unlikely outcomes during early practice trials on subsequent behavior (e.g., a balloon exploding after the first pump). However, this instruction deviates from previous implementations of the BART. We cannot know the impact of this deviation on task performance, but there are two reasons why we do not believe this instruction heavily influenced group-level risk-taking behavior. 1) Very few participants received this instruction, and it was not limited to one group. 2) BART practice trials concluded at least 30 minutes before the initiation of actual BART fMRI-based data collection. During that in-between time, participants completed practice trials for a separate task and completed other MRI related procedures (e.g., ambulating to the imaging suite, safety screener, changing clothes, setup scans). This adds a buffer time before the actual task. This instruction was never restated prior to the actual BART data collection.

div.head: Reparameterized 4-parameter model (Par4):
div.p: The first assumption of the Par4 model is that participants have a subjective belief (i.e., not based on task design) about the probability that inflating the balloon will make it explode, which is based on their prior belief ( ) and learning rate ( ). This subjective belief ( ) is updated after each trial:

The prior belief ( ) is the initial belief that inflating the balloon will NOT make it explode (i.e., prior belief about a successful inflation). The learning rate ( ) reflects the degree to which participants update their subjective belief ( ) based on observations across trials. If the learning rate ( ) is zero, the subjective belief would not be affected by observations across trials but continue to reflect the participants prior belief ( ). As learning rate ( ) increases, the subjective belief more closely reflects the observed probability of explosion (i.e., the ratio of successful inflations to total number of inflations). Finally, i is the indexing variable which iterates through the values specified in the range from i=0 to k-1, where k is the trial number. Of note, i is not equal to inflation number, represented by l.

The second assumption of the Par4 model is that participants determine their optimal number of inflations before each trial, thus the par4 model does not consider inter-trial dynamics. Based on prospect theory (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979), the expected utility after l inflations on trial k, ( ) is:

In this equation, r is the amount of reward gained per successful inflation. Under this second assumption, the first derivative of this equation with respect the number of inflations (l) is set to zero, reflecting the participants optimal number of inflations ( ) on a given trial k:

The optimal number of inflations is based on the participant's subjective belief of the balloon exploding ( ) and their estimated risk propensity ( ). Risk propensity (range: > 0) values mirror prospect theory, where values between 0 < < 1 indicates risk-aversion and > 1 indicates risk-seeking. Finally, the probability the participant will inflate the balloon ( ) is calculated for inflation l of trial k:

Here, the probability of inflating the balloon is based on the optimal number of inflations ( ) and the estimated inverse temperature ( ), where higher values indicate more deterministic behavior or behavioral consistency.
Taken together, the Par4 model results in four parameters estimated from the participants behavior: risk propensity ( ), prior belief ( ), learning rate ( ), and inverse temperature ( ).

div.head: Exponential-weight mean-variance model (EWMV):
div.p: The first assumption of the EWMV model is that participants have a subjective belief (i.e., not based on task design) about the probability that inflating the balloon will make it explode, based on their prior belief ( ) and learning rate ( ). This subjective belief ( ), is updated after each trial:

In the EWMV model, the prior belief ( ) represents the participants initial belief that inflating the balloon WILL make it explode (i.e., prior belief of balloon exploding). Thus, higher values for the prior belief ( ) indicate a belief that the balloon is more likely to explode. The subjective belief that the balloon will explode ( ) is represented as the weighted average of the participants prior belief ( ) and the observed probability of the balloon exploding (i.e., the ratio of the number of exploded balloons to the total number of inflations). The weight given to observation depends on the amount of evidence accumulated and the learning rate (ξ). Higher values for the learning rate (ξ) indicate the participant more readily incorporates new evidence and therefore the subjective belief will more closely reflect the observed probability of the balloon exploding. Finally, i is the indexing variable which iterates through the values specified in the range from i=0 to k-1, where k is the trial number. Of note, i is not equal to inflation number, represented by l.

The second assumption of the EWMV model is that the probability of inflating (versus cashing out/stopping) depends on the participants subjective belief that the balloon will explode ( ) as well as subjective utilities for inflating ( ) and stopping ( ). The subjective utility of stopping ( ) is fixed at 0 because stopping does not add any further reward to the balloon. The subjective utility of inflating ( ) is represented as:

The subjective utility of inflating the balloon is based on the subjective belief that inflating the balloon will make it explode ( ), the amount of reward at a given inflation ( ), the participants risk preference (ρ), and their aversion to loss ( ). In this equation, risk preference (ρ) is defined as a coefficient of the variance term. Here ρ < 0 indicates preference for an option with a large variance of potential outcomes, ρ = 0 indicates the expected value of an option determines the participant's subjective utility, and ρ > 0 indicates preference for an option with a small variance of potential outcomes. Higher values for loss aversion (λ) reflect greater aversion to potential losses relative to attraction to potential rewards.

In contrast to the Par4 model, the EWMV model does consider inter-trial dynamics. Specifically, is updated before each pump, and takes into consideration the current reward for pumping, r, and how much they could potentially lose [( − 1) ].
Finally, the probability that the participant will inflate the balloon ( ) is calculated for inflation l of trial k:

The probability of inflating the balloon is based on the difference between the subjective utility of stopping( ) and inflating ( ), and the participants estimated inverse temperature (τ). Higher values for inverse temperature (τ) indicate behavior that is more deterministic or consistent with the subjective utility.

Taken together, the EWMV model results in five computational parameters estimated from participants behavior: risk preference (ρ), prior belief (ψ), loss aversion (λ), learning rate (ξ), and inverse temperature(τ). Changes to the EWMV model can be found on GitHub: Repository for added reward values. Since reward was a non-constant value, we added two arrays which are used to calculate . First, we added an array, termed u_gain_array, reflecting the amount of potential reward for a given pump number. The second array, termed u_lose_array, replaced [( − 1) ] to capture the total amount of money the balloon was worth at a given inflation, and thus how much the participant could lose.

There are 3 key differences between the Par4 and EWMV model. The EWMV model uses a different updating process, reflected in , such that the subjective belief about the balloon exploding is a weighted average of the initial belief and observations, which are updated with new data. Second, the EWMV model removes the assumption that participants determine the optimal number of pumps before a trial, instead the participants decision to pump, reflected in , is updated before each pump. Finally, the EWMV model utilizes mean-variance analysis (Markowitz, 1952) to calculate subjective utilities, instead of prospect theory (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979); however, previous studies suggest they are comparable ).
Supplementary Result

div.head: Posterior Predictive Checks
div.p: Posterior predictive checks were completed for all models using the inc_postpred function of the hBayesDM package. This provides predicted behavior based on estimated model parameters. Specifically, each model contained 16000 MCMC samples of predicted behavior (i.e., 6000 samples [minus 2000 burn-in] by 4 MCMC chains) at each inflation opportunity for all balloons. From the predicted behavior, we calculated the predicted adjusted pumps. To derive predicted adjusted pumps, we simulated the task and excluded samples where predictions exceeded a simulated explosion point. The predicted adjusted pumps were then compared to the observed adjusted pumps for each participant, assessing the model's ability to accurately predict behavior. The predicted adjusted pumps were correlated with observed adjusted pumps (Spearman ρ's = 0.69-0.86; Supplemental Figure 2) for all models. All models for all groups underestimated observed adjusted pumps when observed adjusted pumps ≥5. The control group had a narrow range of adjusted pumps, limiting interpretation of how these models performed at fewer observed adjusted pumps for this group. However, focusing on the Par4 model, there appears to be a trend toward over-estimating observed adjusted pumps across groups when observed adjusted pumps is ≤ 4.

1 Figure S2. Posterior predictive checks for the Par4 and EWMV models; each model was run separately for the SZ and CP groups. Black lines represent a x=y linear function. Red lines represent Spearman Rank correlations (rho = R), which are also reported on the graph. Finally, error bars depict the 95% HDI of the predicted adjusted pumps estimate for each subject.

div.head: Parameter Recovery
div.p: Parameter recovery was used to evaluate how well the Par4 model recovered parameter estimates from simulated data (i.e., pumping behavior and whether the balloon exploded) generated from "true" parameters (e.g., van Ravenzwaaij et al., 2011; Lasagna et al., 2022). We focus on the Par4 model, as the parameters from this model were used in group difference tests and general linear models; however, parameter recovery for the EWMV models is briefly reported. Group-level posterior estimates for each group were used to generate simulated samples of behavioral data for each group (i.e., CP and SZ separately). Specifically, group-level means and standard deviations for the posterior parameter estimates were utilized to sample true parameters for 30 simulated participants. Next, these true parameters were used to generate 50 trials of BART behavior (i.e., pumps and whether the balloon exploded) per simulated participant. Finally, this simulated dataset (i.e., 30 simulated participants with 50 trials of behavior) was fit to the model, resulting in parameter estimates that could be compared to the true parameters. This process was repeated 50 times. The models were fit using 4 MCMC chains of 6,000 samples (2,000 burnin).

div.head: Parameter Recovery: Par4 Model
div.p: Across groups, the par4 model simulations (i.e., 95% HDI of the group-level simulation estimates) failed to recover true parameters for Risk Propensity ( ), Prior Belief ( ), and Learning Rate ( ), ranging from 0%-24% of the simulations containing the true parameter (i.e., original group-level posterior mean). The Par4 model simulations performed better at recovering Inverse Temperature ( ), with 52%-64% of simulations containing the true parameter. Overall, the Par4 model failed to recover precise parameter estimates (Table S4; Figure S3). This is in part due to very narrow parameter distributions for Risk Propensity, Prior Belief, and Learning Rate. Further, the estimation of Risk Propensity is impacted by the estimation of Prior Belief, and Learning Rate. Thus, precise values for the Par4 model parameters should be interpreted with caution. However, it is important to note the pattern of underestimating Risk Propensity, Learning Rate, and Inverse Temperature, while overestimating Prior belief was consistent across groups. Critically, given our use of Risk Propensity in linear models, we did see significant correlations between true and estimated parameters for Risk Propensity (SZ: r = 0.26, p <0.001; CP: r = 0.15, p <0.001). Demonstrating that risk propensity estimates reflect actual signal present in the behavioral data, since we were able to account for significant variance in the true parameter with our estimated parameters. The correlation between true and estimated parameters for the rest of the Par4 parameters are as follows: Prior Belief (SZ: r = 0.08, p <0.001; CP: r = 0.03, p = 0.23), Learning Rate (SZ: r = 0.12, p <0.001; CP: r = 0.10, p <0.001), and Inverse Temperature (SZ: r = 0.29, p <0.001; CP: r = 0.30, p <0.001). Since poor recoverability of the precise estimates is due to a general bias, the order of the values is expected to be preserved. Spearman correlations, which rely on rank rather than precise values, were used to account for this general bias in main analyses. Across the 50 simulated datasets, we calculated the percentage of times we recovered original group differences, or lack thereof (Table S5). Specifically, when randomly sampling 'true parameters' from the group-level posterior distributions for the simulations, the amount of variance within and between these group-level distributions will determine how often we observe our original group difference in Table S5. If we consistently observe our original group difference, then we can be confident it is not due to chance sampling. Although reversals are possible based on randomly sampling from extreme ends of the grouplevel distributions. Original group differences for Risk Propensity (78%) and Learning Rate (94%) were reliably recovered. Group differences were less reliably recovered for Prior Belief (66%) and Inverse Temperature (34%). Figure S3. Parameter recovery of the Par4 model. In red is the mean and 95% HDI of the posterior distribution for the 50 simulations, for each parameter. In blue is the true mean and 95% HDI of the original posterior distribution, for each parameter. A simulation is considered to recover the true value if the true posterior mean falls within the 95% HDI for the simulation. A vertical line has been superimposed to facilitate interpretation. (A) CP = Comparison Participants; (B) SZ = Participants with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder.

div.head: Parameter Recovery: EWMV Model
div.p: As with the Par4 model, the EWMV model systematically over or underestimated parameters across groups. Specifically, Risk Preference (ρ), Prior Belief (ψ), Learning Rate (ξ), and Inverse Temperature ( ) were consistently underestimated, while Loss Aversion (λ) was systematically overestimated. Thus, the EWMV model failed to recover precise parameter estimates and parameter values should be interpreted with caution. Previous clinical samples utilizing the standard version of the BART, also failed to recover precise parameter estimates from the EWMV model . Figure S4. Spearman rank correlations (rho = R) between corresponding computational parameters from the Par4 and EWMV models. Black lines represent regression trend lines and shaded regions indicate 95% confidence intervals.

div.head: Group differences in EWMV Model Parameters
div.p: The EWMV model consisted of five parameters: risk preference (ρ), prior belief (ψ), loss aversion (λ), learning rate (ξ), and inverse temperature (τ). Relative to CP, participants with SZ exhibited lower risk preferences

div.head: Specificity Correlational Analyses
div.p: As reported in the main manuscript, IQ was positively correlated with Risk Propensity (Spearman ρ = 0.34, p < 0.01). Correlation coefficients were not significantly different between groups (SZ: ρ = 0.43; CT: ρ = 0.29). In the full sample, IQ was not correlated with Prior Belief of Success (Spearman ρ = -0.12, p = 0.35) and although correlation coefficients were not significantly different between groups, the associations due appear qualitatively different (SZ: ρ = -0.41; CT: ρ = 0.04).

Our second aim was focused specifically on computational parameters capturing risk-taking tendencies, and thus we had not tested relationships between Prior Belief of Success ( ) and any self-report measure, including Defeatist Performance Beliefs. However, given that both measures are directly related to belief systems, we now report an exploratory correlation between Prior Beliefs of Success and Defeatist Performance. In the combined sample, Prior Belief of Success was not significantly correlated with Defeatist Performance Beliefs (Spearman ρ = 0.12, p = 0.35) and correlation coefficients were not significantly different between groups (SZ: ρ = -0.06; CT: ρ = 0.10).

div.head: Specificity Analyses for interaction between IQ and Perceived Risk on Risk Propensity
div.p: To better understand what aspects of general intelligence (IQ) may be driving the relationship between IQ and risk propensity, we replicated model 2 using letter number sequencing (LNS) and digit symbol (DS). The models corroborated the findings with IQ. In separate linear models, there continued to be a significant interaction between LNS/DS and perceived risk (Perceived Risk*LNS: β = -0.33, p <0.01; Perceived Risk*DS: β = -0.25, p <0.01).

div.head: Sensitivity Analysis
div.p: Utilizing GPower, we conducted a sensitivity analysis to determine what effect size we are powered to detect, based on our sample size (two groups of 30 participants) and number of variables utilized in our linear models (2 covariates [IQ & Perceived Risk] and interaction terms). The study is powered to detect a medium effect (Effect size f = 0.37). Next, we approximated the effect size reported by GPower to Cohen's ( = √ 1− ). Based on the approximation we could detect a medium Cohen's effect size of ( = 0.77). Next, we approximated the Cohen's effect size of the two interaction terms in our final model via ( = √ ), where the MSE for the final model is 0.534. Thus, the effect size for the interaction between Perceived Risk and group was medium ( = 0.62) and the effect size for the interaction between Perceived Risk and IQ was small ( = 0.33). 23

B) Group differences in parameters were assessed by calculating the 95% HDI of the difference in posterior distributions (i.e., CP-SZ). * = credible difference in posterior differences. NS = non-significant difference in posterior difference. M = mean of the posterior difference and gives an indication of effect size. C) Loss Aversion from the EWMV model included for reference because this metric does not have an analogous parameter in the Par4 model.

Model 1 β = -0.72 [-1.15 -0.30], t = -3.43, p = 0.001 β = 0.31 [0.09 0.53], t = 2.84, p = 0.006 β = -0.22 [-0.51 0.08], t = -1.49, p = 0.142 β = 0.63 [0.20 1.07], t = 2.90, p = 0.005 -(F(54) = 9.07, p<0.001) Model 2 β = -0.62 [-1.05 -0.20], t = -2.97, p = 0.004 β = 0.34 [0.13 0.56], t = 3.26, p = 0.002 β = 0.01 [-0.21 0.23], t = 0.10, p = 0] = 95% confidence interval; * = interaction term; IQ = Intelligence; Perceived Risk = Perceived risk of financial decisions from the Domain Specific Risk-Taking Scale (DOSPERT).

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: A) Interaction between Perceived Risk and Group from Model 1. Perceived Risk and Risk Propensity (γ)

participants across both groups had high Prior Beliefs of Success [values >0.88, where 1 is the max value]), and the finding was less replicable in parameter recovery simulations (~¼ of simulations with no difference between groups) due to largely overlapping group-level distributions, limiting interpretability of this finding. Within the SZ group, Prior Belief of Success correlated with neuroleptic dosage, indicating higher doses were associated with greater beliefs of success. It is possible that those with higher doses of pharmacological treatment began the task with beliefs which would foster adaptive choice (i.e., pursuing success), but due to the novelty of this finding and the aforementioned modeling caveats, this possible interpretation is highly speculative. Toward our second aim, linear models examined several factors (i.e., risk-specific processes and non-risk specific traits) for relationships with Risk Propensity, to disentangle what contributes to individual differences in risk-attitudes in SZ. Specifically, risk-specific processes of Financial Perceived Risk and Expected Benefit were of interest because they offer insight into factors contributing to decision-making behavior. In contrast, defeatist beliefs and hedonic tone were examined to preclude the possibility that risk-taking tendencies were better explained by non-risk specific traits that have been theorized to impact decision-making broadly. While our findings are largely consistent with our hypotheses and previous research, our linear model results are interpreted with caution given that computational models were unable to recover precise parameter estimates. Our main linear model utilized self-reported Perceived Risk on the DOSPERT, representing one's assessment of the level of risk associated with financial situations (without regard to one's likelihood of taking said risk or the expected benefit). Within CP, who on average took more advantageous risks than SZ, there is not a significant relationship between Perceived Financial Risk and the computational Risk Propensity parameter based on BART behavior. That is, CP tended to demonstrate advantageous Risk Propensity irrespective of their self-reported perception of risk in real-world risky situations. This aligns with previous literature

figure.head: Financial
figure.figDesc: Risk scores were associated with lower computationally derived Risk Propensity. This highlights, within this subsample, that perceiving risk and leveraging risk perception may be important to advantageously pursuing risky rewards. Thus, a more wide-spread investigation of cognition in decision-making is warranted, even when matching clinical and non-clinical groups on IQ. Our other linear models examined self-reported Expected Benefits of risk-taking and non-risk specific traits (i.e., defeatist beliefs; hedonic tone) as predictors of Risk Propensity. Expected Benefit of financial situations was unrelated to the Risk Propensity parameter.

BART implementation deviated from previous studies in several ways. First, BART practice was shorter than previous fMRI-based implementations and, if a balloon was not inflated at least 4 times, included a nonchalant instruction on the last practice trial to ensure all participants knew the balloon could be inflated at least 4 times. While this may have some advantages, see Supplementary Section 1.2., we do not know how this instruction impacted task behavior for the few participants wo received it. Further, in this version of the BART, explosion risk and reward values are highly correlated, there are fewer maximum inflations per trial (12 instead of 128), and there is a nonlinear increase in reward. The Par4 model assumes that reward is a constant value. Although this contradicts the task design, the Par4 model outperformed the EWMV model, which captured task specific reward values. Thus, participants may not utilize this information during decision-making. Second, precise parameter estimates were not recovered with either computational model, limiting interpretation of correlations and linear models. Furthermore, since models were estimated by groups, individual parameter estimates are biased toward the group estimate, impacting correlation analyses.67 To further assess the model's accuracy at predicting behavior, we compared the model's predicted adjusted pumps to observed adjusted pumps, for each participant (Supplementary Section 2.1). Across both models and groups, predicted adjusted pumps were correlated with observed adjusted pumps (Spearman ρ's = 0.69-0.86; Supplemental

figure.head: Domain Specific Risk-Taking Scale (DOSPERT): The
figure.figDesc: or one's ability to experience pleasure, where low hedonic tone represents a reduced capacity to experience pleasure.53 Each item was rated from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). Unlike previous implementations, our scale anchors were unintentionally inverted, thus higher scores indicate greater hedonic tone.

row.cell: Benefit of Risks subscales from the DOSPERT were administered. 21,51 Each subscale included
five domains of risky situations: Ethical, Financial, Health/Safety, Recreational, and Social. The
current study utilized the financial domain score, as it best resembles monetary uncertain-risk
decision-making on the BART. For each financial situation, participants indicated how risky they
perceived the situation (i.e., Perceived Risk) and the benefits they would obtain from the
situation (i.e., Expected Benefits) on a Likert scale from 1 (not at all risky/no benefits at all) to 7
(extremely risky/great benefits). Higher scores indicate greater Perceived Risk and greater
Expected Benefit, within their respective subscale domains.
Non-Risk Specific traits: The Defeatist Performance Scale (DPS) is a 15-item measure of
defeatist beliefs, or negative appraisals about one's ability to complete goal-directed tasks. 52
Items are rated from 1 (disagree totally) to 7 (agree totally), where higher scores indicate greater
defeatist beliefs. The Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (SHAPS) is a 14-item scale measuring

figure.note: 54 Cognitive Assessments: General intelligence (IQ) was assessed via the Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI) two sub-test form (Matrix Reasoning and Vocabulary).55 Letter number sequencing and digit symbol from the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS-III), which both require sustained attention, were also assessed as measures of working memory and processing speed, respectively. 56

figure.figDesc: while approximately two-thirds of SZ participants had comparable Risk Propensity estimates to CP, one-third of SZ participants had Risk Propensity estimates below the lowest Risk Propensity parameter in the CP group. SZ participants also had higher initial Prior Beliefs of Success (φ). There were no group differences in Learning Rate (η) or Behavioral Consistency (τ). Groups did not differ in the unique EWMV model parameter of Loss Aversion (λ).

row.cell: Overlapping parameters from the Par4 and EWMV models showed consistent group difference

figure.figDesc: the combined sample, IQ was positively correlated with Risk Propensity (Spearman ρ = 0.34, p < 0.01), indicating those with lower IQ tended to take less risks for reward. IQ was not associated with Prior Belief of Success (Spearman ρ = -0.12, p = 0.35). Correlation coefficients did not significantly differ between groups. CPZ equivalent dose in SZ was not associated with Risk Propensity (Spearman ρ = 0.23, p = 0.24); however, CPZ equivalent dose was negatively correlated with Prior Belief of Success (Spearman ρ = -0.44, p = 0.02). See supplementary section 2.6 for specificity correlation analyses.

Model 1, self-reported Perceived Risk about financial situations did not predict the Risk Propensity parameter in the whole sample, but there was a significant interaction between Perceived Risk and group (p < 0.01; Model 1, Table 2), such that Perceived Risk and Risk Propensity were positively correlated within the SZ group (Spearman ρ = 0.47, p = 0.01) and not significantly correlated within the CP group (Spearman ρ = -0.25, p = 0.19). IQ continued to be significantly related to Risk Propensity in this model. Model 2 identified a significant interaction between self-reported Perceived Risk about financial situations and IQ (p < 0.01; Model 2,Table 2). To interpret and graph the interaction, we used a median split of IQ (median = 109.5), which resulted in an equal number of SZ and CP participants above and below the median. Individuals with below median IQ demonstrated a positive relationship between Perceived Risk and the Risk Propensity parameter (Spearman ρ = 0.37, p = 0.03), while there was a non-significant relationship in the above median IQ group (Spearman ρ = -0.17, p = 0.36;Figure 2). Group continued to be significantly related to Risk Propensity in this model. This model was replicated when replacing IQ with DS, and separately LNS, as other measures of cognition (see Supplementary Section 2.6).Forward stepwise regression was used to identify whether both interaction terms from the above models, or other interactions, should be included. Based on Bayesian Information Criteria, which penalizes for added parameters (thus preferring simpler models), the final best fitting model included significant interactions between Perceived Risk and IQ, as well as between

figure.figDesc: Twenty additional clinical subjects completed part of the research protocol, but data was incomplete and excluded for the following reasons: 3 metallic MRI contraindications, 3 unclear diagnosis (no medical records), 3 diagnosis of bipolar disorder with psychotic features, 3 positive drug screens, 2 lack of psychosis (via interview and medical records), 2 self-elected discontinuations, 1 brain lesion, 1 extreme discomfort in MRI, 1 refusal of cognitive testing, 1 left-handed. Nineteen comparison participants completed part of the research protocol, but data was incomplete and excluded for the following reasons: 6 lack of IQ match with clinical participants, 3 positive drug screens, 2 MRI scanner failures, 2 history of substance use disorder, 2 familial history of severe mental illness, 2 current or previous mental health diagnoses, 1 extreme discomfort in MRI, 1 metallic MRI contraindication.

div.head: Acknowledgements:
div.p: Research was possible thanks to Centerstone Research Center and IU Imaging Research Facility.
The authors thank Bess Bloomer, Catherine Jones, Melissa Ritter, Rachel Tullar, and Madison Walker for recruitment and data collection, as well as Carly Lasagna for input on modeling analyses.

div.head: Funding:
div.p: This research was supported in part by the NIMH [T32MH103213 (ENH & JRP);

div.head: Data Accessibility:
div.p: Regretfully, the data from this project are not publicly available, as this was not explicitly included in the consent form at the time of data collection, however de-identified data may be requested from the senior author J. Purcell for secondary data analyses.

div.head: Competing interests:
div.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interests. , 2002), to determine psychosis-like experiences across all subjects. Urine drug screening ruled out non-prescription use of methamphetamine, cocaine, amphetamine, opioids, or benzodiazepines. Five participants with schizophrenia screened positive for cannabis without abuse/dependence.

div.head: Education Information
div.p: Education data was collected on an ordinal scale. The authors prefer the use of IQ, rather than highest education attained, as subjects frequently endorsed difficulty pursuing educational endeavors due to symptom exacerbation or functional difficulties. Studies have also demonstrated a clear gap in education attainment in SZ (Crossley et al., 2022). While IQ can be a problematic measure in itself, we find it appropriate for the purposes of comparing gross intellectual functioning within and across our groups.
